# Draft:1900; or, The Last President

1900; or, The Last President is a book written in 1896 by American author and lawyer Ingersoll Lockwood in which the United States is brought to its downfall following the election of a populist candidate in 1896.
Synopsis
After William Jennings Bryan becomes president of the United States following his victory in the 1896 election, he signs a bill that repeals the Coinage Act of 1873 and allows for silver coins ("Bryan Dollars") to be freely minted at 16:1 parity with gold dollars. However, the government fails to regulate the production of Bryan Dollars, and by the autumn of 1898, their value eventually drops to a third of the value of gold dollars. Revolts begin to break out in northern states in 1899, and a proposal is made to dissolve the U.S. into three countries, one of which would have New York City as its capital. On the night of December 31, a prolonged Congressional session is interrupted by an explosion of dynamite which destroys the dome of the Capitol at midnight.
